carbon_footprint.title: Carbon Footprint Calculator
carbon_footprint.description: Estimate total carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions resulting from your energy consumption, transportation, and diet.
carbon_footprint.electricity_tooltip: Enter your average monthly consumption from your electricity bill
carbon_footprint.gas_tooltip: Enter your average monthly natural gas consumption
carbon_footprint.car_tooltip: Average distance you travel in your private car
carbon_footprint.flights_tooltip: Total number of hours spent on flights per year
carbon_footprint.diet_tooltip: Your diet type significantly impacts your carbon emissions
carbon_footprint.comparison_low: Your carbon footprint is very low! You are eco-friendly.
carbon_footprint.comparison_average: Your carbon footprint is close to the global average.
carbon_footprint.comparison_high: Your carbon footprint is high. Try to reduce energy consumption or offset emissions.
carbon_footprint.info_description: It is the total sum of greenhouse gases produced by individuals through daily activities. Reducing it helps combat climate change.
carbon_footprint.use_case_1: Use energy-efficient appliances and LED bulbs.
carbon_footprint.use_case_2: Rely more on public transport or cycling.
carbon_footprint.use_case_3: Reduce red meat and dairy consumption.
carbon_footprint.error_at_least_one: Please enter at least one value

howItWorks.title: How Does the Carbon Footprint Calculator Work?
howItWorks.formula: Total CO₂ = (Electricity × 0.5) + (Gas × 2.0) + (Car km × 0.21) + (Flight hours × 90) + Diet emissions
howItWorks.explanation: This tool calculates your total annual carbon dioxide emissions based on energy consumption, transportation, and diet. Each activity is multiplied by a specific emission factor to convert it to CO₂ equivalent.

steps.name: Step 1
steps.text: Enter your monthly electricity consumption in kWh

steps.name: Step 2
steps.text: Enter your monthly natural gas consumption in cubic meters

steps.name: Step 3
steps.text: Enter the monthly distance traveled by car in kilometers

steps.name: Step 4
steps.text: Enter your annual flight hours

steps.name: Step 5
steps.text: Select your diet type

steps.name: Step 6
steps.text: Click Calculate to see your annual carbon footprint

useCases: Assess personal environmental impact and make eco-friendly decisions
Compare your carbon footprint to the global average (4-8 tons/year)
Identify key areas to reduce emissions in daily life
Calculate the number of trees needed to offset annual emissions
seoTips: Carbon footprint measures total greenhouse gases produced by your activities
Global average per person is approximately 4 tons CO₂ per year
Aviation and cars are among the largest sources of individual emissions
A plant-based diet can reduce carbon footprint by up to 50%
One tree absorbs approximately 21 kg of CO₂ per year
commonMistakes: Not accounting for food emissions which represent 25% of carbon footprint
Forgetting to include flight travel which produces very high emissions
Confusing monthly and annual consumption when entering data
Ignoring the impact of heating and cooling on energy consumption

faqs.question: What is an ideal carbon footprint?
faqs.answer: To keep temperature rise below 2°C, individual carbon footprint should be below 2 tons CO₂ per year.

faqs.question: How can I quickly reduce my carbon footprint?
faqs.answer: The biggest impact comes from reducing flights, using public transport, and reducing red meat consumption.

faqs.question: Is carbon offsetting effective?
faqs.answer: Carbon offsetting is helpful but the priority should be reducing emissions first, then offsetting what cannot be avoided.

faqs.question: Why does flying cause high emissions?
faqs.answer: Aircraft burn large amounts of fuel and release emissions at high altitudes, which doubles their climate impact.

faqs.question: How many trees do I need to offset my emissions?
faqs.answer: One tree absorbs about 21 kg CO₂ per year, so to offset 4 tons you need about 190 trees.

water_usage.title: Water Usage Calculator
water_usage.description: Estimate your daily water consumption at home and receive conservation tips.
water_usage.shower_tooltip: Average time spent in the shower
water_usage.toilet_tooltip: How many times you flush the toilet per day
water_usage.dish_tooltip: Times dishes are washed manually or by machine
water_usage.laundry_tooltip: Number of laundry loads per week
water_usage.cost_tooltip: Water price per liter based on local tariff
water_usage.comparison_low: Your water usage is low and ideal.
water_usage.comparison_average: Your usage is within the normal average per individual.
water_usage.comparison_high: Your usage is high. Try using water-saving devices.
water_usage.info_description: Water is a precious and limited resource. Conserving usage protects the environment and reduces your monthly bills.
water_usage.use_case_1: Take shorter showers and install water-saving showerheads.
water_usage.use_case_2: Fix leaks promptly and use water-efficient appliances.
water_usage.use_case_3: Water plants early morning or late evening to reduce evaporation.
water_usage.error_at_least_one: Please enter at least one value

howItWorks.title: How Does the Water Usage Calculator Work?
howItWorks.formula: Daily Usage = (Shower minutes × 10L) + (Toilet flushes × 6L) + (Dishwashing × 15L) + (Laundry loads × 50L/7)
howItWorks.explanation: This calculator estimates your daily water consumption by analyzing common household activities. Each activity uses a standard water flow rate to calculate total consumption.

steps.name: Step 1
steps.text: Enter your average daily shower duration in minutes

steps.name: Step 2
steps.text: Enter the number of toilet flushes per day

steps.name: Step 3
steps.text: Enter how many times you wash dishes daily

steps.name: Step 4
steps.text: Enter your weekly laundry loads

steps.name: Step 5
steps.text: Optionally enter your local water cost per liter

steps.name: Step 6
steps.text: Click Calculate to see your daily, monthly, and yearly water usage

useCases: Track household water consumption to identify wasteful habits
Estimate monthly and annual water bills for budgeting
Compare your usage against average consumption (100-150 liters/day)
Identify which activities consume the most water
seoTips: Average person uses 100-150 liters of water daily
A 10-minute shower uses approximately 100 liters of water
Fixing a dripping tap can save 20 liters per day
Water-efficient showerheads reduce consumption by 40%
Dual-flush toilets use 50% less water than traditional toilets
commonMistakes: Underestimating shower duration - most people shower longer than they think
Forgetting to count all toilet flushes throughout the day
Not accounting for water used in cooking and drinking
Ignoring outdoor water usage like gardening and car washing

faqs.question: What is considered high water usage?
faqs.answer: Using more than 150 liters per person per day is considered high. The sustainable target is below 100 liters per day.

faqs.question: How can I reduce shower water usage?
faqs.answer: Install a low-flow showerhead, take shorter showers (5 minutes max), and turn off water while lathering.

faqs.question: Does a dishwasher use more water than hand washing?
faqs.answer: Modern efficient dishwashers typically use 10-15 liters per cycle, while hand washing can use 40-60 liters for the same dishes.

faqs.question: How much water does a toilet flush use?
faqs.answer: Traditional toilets use 9-12 liters per flush, while modern dual-flush toilets use 3-6 liters.

faqs.question: What percentage of household water is used for bathing?
faqs.answer: Bathing and showering typically account for 30-35% of household water consumption.

co2_emissions.title: CO₂ Emissions Calculator
co2_emissions.description: Calculate CO₂ emissions from daily activities and energy consumption
co2_emissions.fact_trees: One tree absorbs about 21 kg of CO₂ annually
co2_emissions.fact_car: Average car produces about 4.6 tons CO₂ annually
co2_emissions.fact_emissions: Emissions vary by energy source and efficiency
co2_emissions.empty_state: Enter activity details to calculate CO₂ emissions
co2_emissions.footer_note: These calculations are based on standard global emission factors.

howItWorks.title: How Does the CO₂ Emissions Calculator Work?
howItWorks.formula: CO₂ = Amount × Emission Factor (varies by fuel type)
howItWorks.explanation: This calculator converts your energy consumption or fuel usage into equivalent CO₂ emissions using standardized emission factors for each fuel type.

steps.name: Step 1
steps.text: Select the activity or fuel type from the dropdown

steps.name: Step 2
steps.text: Enter the amount consumed in the specified unit

steps.name: Step 3
steps.text: Click Calculate to see your CO₂ emissions

steps.name: Step 4
steps.text: View the equivalent number of trees needed to offset emissions

useCases: Calculate emissions from specific fuel consumption for reporting
Compare environmental impact of different energy sources
Track business or household carbon emissions over time
Plan carbon offset strategies based on actual emissions
seoTips: Coal produces the highest CO₂ per unit of energy (2.42 kg CO₂/kg)
Natural gas is cleaner than coal, producing 2.0 kg CO₂/m³
Electricity emissions depend on the grid mix (0.5 kg CO₂/kWh average)
Diesel produces slightly more CO₂ than petrol per liter
One tree absorbs approximately 21 kg of CO₂ per year
commonMistakes: Using incorrect units (liters vs gallons, kWh vs MWh)
Not accounting for all emission sources in a calculation
Forgetting upstream emissions from fuel production
Assuming all electricity has the same carbon intensity

faqs.question: Which fuel produces the most CO₂?
faqs.answer: Coal produces the most CO₂ per unit of energy, followed by diesel, petrol, and natural gas. Renewable energy produces zero direct emissions.

faqs.question: How accurate are these emission factors?
faqs.answer: These are internationally standardized average emission factors. Actual emissions may vary by fuel quality and combustion efficiency.

faqs.question: Why does electricity have CO₂ emissions?
faqs.answer: Most electricity is generated from fossil fuels. The emission factor depends on your local grid mix of coal, gas, nuclear, and renewables.

faqs.question: How many trees offset 1 tonne of CO₂?
faqs.answer: Approximately 48 mature trees are needed to absorb 1 tonne of CO₂ per year, as each tree absorbs about 21 kg annually.

carbon_offset.title: Carbon Offset Calculator
carbon_offset.description: Calculate required carbon offset and available options
carbon_offset.tip_native: Planting native trees is more effective for local environment
carbon_offset.tip_renewable: Renewable energy provides continuous long-term offset
carbon_offset.tip_certified: Ensure certified and reliable offset programs
carbon_offset.tip_reduce: Best approach is to reduce emissions before offsetting
carbon_offset.empty_state: Enter CO₂ amount to calculate offset options
carbon_offset.footer_note: Estimates are based on annual absorption averages and may vary by conditions.

howItWorks.title: How Does the Carbon Offset Calculator Work?
howItWorks.formula: Trees needed = CO₂ (kg) ÷ 21 kg/tree/year | Solar panels = CO₂ ÷ 400 kg/panel/year
howItWorks.explanation: This calculator determines how many trees, solar panels, or wind turbines are needed to offset a given amount of CO₂ emissions based on their average annual carbon absorption or displacement rates.

steps.name: Step 1
steps.text: Enter the amount of CO₂ you want to offset in kilograms

steps.name: Step 2
steps.text: Select your preferred offset method

steps.name: Step 3
steps.text: Click Calculate to see offset requirements

steps.name: Step 4
steps.text: View estimated costs and land area needed

useCases: Plan tree planting initiatives to achieve carbon neutrality
Compare costs of different carbon offset strategies
Calculate land requirements for offset projects
Budget for corporate or personal carbon offset programs
seoTips: One mature tree absorbs approximately 21 kg CO₂ per year
A typical solar panel offsets about 400 kg CO₂ annually
Wind turbines can offset 1,000+ tonnes of CO₂ per year
Carbon offset costs range from $10-50 per tonne of CO₂
Native trees are more effective for local ecosystems
commonMistakes: Expecting instant results - trees take years to reach full absorption capacity
Not accounting for maintenance costs and tree mortality
Choosing offset methods without considering local conditions
Relying solely on offsets instead of reducing emissions first

faqs.question: Is tree planting the best offset method?
faqs.answer: Tree planting is effective but slow. Renewable energy provides immediate, verifiable offsets. A mixed approach is often recommended.

faqs.question: How long until planted trees start absorbing significant CO₂?
faqs.answer: Trees absorb CO₂ from day one, but reach peak absorption at 10-20 years of age. Young trees absorb less than mature ones.

faqs.question: Are carbon offsets reliable?
faqs.answer: Choose certified programs (Gold Standard, Verified Carbon Standard) to ensure offsets are real, additional, and permanent.

faqs.question: Should I offset or reduce emissions?
faqs.answer: Always prioritize reducing emissions first. Offsetting should complement reduction efforts, not replace them.

faqs.question: What is the cost per tonne of CO₂ offset?
faqs.answer: Quality carbon offsets typically cost $15-50 per tonne, depending on the project type and certification standard.

composting.title: Composting Calculator
composting.description: Calculate compost production from your waste
composting.tip_balance: Maintain balance between green (nitrogen) and brown (carbon) materials
composting.tip_turn: Turn pile regularly to provide oxygen
composting.empty_state: Enter organic waste amount to calculate compost production
composting.footer_note: Composting reduces waste and naturally improves soil health.

howItWorks.title: How Does the Composting Calculator Work?
howItWorks.formula: Annual Compost = (Food waste + Yard waste) × 52 weeks × Conversion rate (30-50%)
howItWorks.explanation: This calculator estimates how much finished compost you can produce from organic waste, along with the environmental benefits of diverting waste from landfills.

steps.name: Step 1
steps.text: Enter your weekly food waste in kilograms

steps.name: Step 2
steps.text: Enter your weekly yard waste (leaves, grass, branches)

steps.name: Step 3
steps.text: Select your composting method

steps.name: Step 4
steps.text: Click Calculate to see annual compost production

steps.name: Step 5
steps.text: View methane prevented and garden area benefited

useCases: Plan home composting systems based on waste volume
Calculate environmental benefits of composting for sustainability reports
Determine appropriate compost bin size for your household
Estimate compost available for garden fertilization
seoTips: Composting reduces waste sent to landfills by 30-40%
Organic waste in landfills produces methane, 25x worse than CO₂
Finished compost is about 30-50% of original waste volume
Compost enriches soil and reduces need for chemical fertilizers
Worm composting produces nutrient-rich vermicompost
commonMistakes: Adding meat, dairy, or oils which attract pests and slow decomposition
Not maintaining proper carbon-to-nitrogen ratio (ideal is 30:1)
Keeping compost too wet or too dry
Not turning the pile regularly for proper aeration

faqs.question: How long does composting take?
faqs.answer: Hot composting takes 1-3 months, cold composting 6-12 months, and worm composting 3-6 months depending on conditions.

faqs.question: What is the ideal carbon-to-nitrogen ratio?
faqs.answer: The ideal C:N ratio is 25-30:1. Browns (leaves, cardboard) provide carbon, greens (food scraps, grass) provide nitrogen.

faqs.question: Can I compost in winter?
faqs.answer: Yes, composting slows but continues. Insulate your bin and add more browns. A tumbler works better in cold climates.

faqs.question: How much compost do I need for my garden?
faqs.answer: Apply 2-5 cm of compost annually. One square meter of garden needs about 20-50 kg of compost per year.

faqs.question: Why does my compost smell bad?
faqs.answer: Bad odors indicate too much nitrogen (greens) or too much moisture. Add brown materials and turn the pile to improve aeration.

diet_footprint.title: Diet Carbon Footprint Calculator
diet_footprint.description: Calculate carbon footprint of your diet
diet_footprint.fact_beef: Beef produces 10x more emissions than chicken
diet_footprint.fact_plant: Plant-based diet reduces carbon footprint by 50%
diet_footprint.fact_reduce: Reducing red meat 1 day/week saves 230 kg CO₂ annually
diet_footprint.empty_state: Enter your food consumption to calculate carbon footprint
diet_footprint.footer_note: Food accounts for 26% of global greenhouse gas emissions.

howItWorks.title: How Does the Diet Carbon Footprint Calculator Work?
howItWorks.formula: Annual CO₂ = Σ (Food type × kg/week × Emission factor × 52)
howItWorks.explanation: This calculator estimates your annual carbon emissions from food consumption by multiplying each food type's emission factor by your weekly consumption.

steps.name: Step 1
steps.text: Enter your weekly beef consumption in kilograms

steps.name: Step 2
steps.text: Enter weekly consumption for chicken, fish, and dairy

steps.name: Step 3
steps.text: Enter vegetable and grain consumption

steps.name: Step 4
steps.text: Click Calculate to see your diet's carbon footprint

steps.name: Step 5
steps.text: View comparison with different diet categories

useCases: Compare environmental impact of different diets
Plan dietary changes to reduce carbon footprint
Calculate potential savings from reducing meat consumption
Educate about food-related environmental impact
seoTips: Beef produces 27 kg CO₂ per kg - the highest of all foods
Chicken produces 6.9 kg CO₂ per kg - 75% less than beef
A vegan diet produces 50% less emissions than meat-heavy diet
Food production accounts for 26% of global greenhouse emissions
Reducing beef by 1 meal/week saves 200+ kg CO₂ annually
commonMistakes: Focusing only on meat while ignoring dairy which also has high emissions
Not considering food waste - wasted food means wasted emissions
Assuming local food is always better (transport is only 10% of food emissions)
Ignoring the impact of food processing and packaging

faqs.question: Which food has the highest carbon footprint?
faqs.answer: Beef has the highest footprint at 27 kg CO₂/kg, followed by lamb (24 kg), cheese (14 kg), and pork (12 kg).

faqs.question: Is being vegetarian better than eating chicken?
faqs.answer: A vegetarian diet typically has lower emissions than any meat diet, but chicken has much lower emissions than beef or lamb.

faqs.question: How much can I reduce by going vegan?
faqs.answer: Switching from a meat-heavy to vegan diet can reduce your food carbon footprint by 50-70%, saving 1-2 tonnes of CO₂ per year.

faqs.question: Does organic food have a lower carbon footprint?
faqs.answer: Not necessarily. Organic farming may use more land and have similar or higher emissions. The food type matters more than organic status.

faqs.question: Is fish a low-carbon alternative?
faqs.answer: Moderately. Fish produces about 5-6 kg CO₂/kg, lower than beef but higher than poultry. Wild-caught varies by fishing method.

energy_saving.title: Energy Saving Calculator
energy_saving.description: Calculate savings from energy efficiency improvements
energy_saving.quantity_tooltip: Number of units or area (depends on type)
energy_saving.tip_payback: Start with improvements having shortest payback period
energy_saving.tip_combine: Combine multiple improvements for best results
energy_saving.tip_finance: Take advantage of green financing programs
energy_saving.empty_state: Enter improvement details to calculate expected savings
energy_saving.footer_note: Estimates are based on average consumption and local prices.

howItWorks.title: How Does the Energy Saving Calculator Work?
howItWorks.formula: Annual Savings = Current Usage × Efficiency Gain × 365 × Electricity Rate
howItWorks.explanation: This calculator estimates potential energy and cost savings from various home efficiency improvements by comparing current consumption with projected consumption after upgrades.

steps.name: Step 1
steps.text: Select the type of energy improvement

steps.name: Step 2
steps.text: Enter your current daily energy usage in kWh

steps.name: Step 3
steps.text: Enter the quantity or number of units

steps.name: Step 4
steps.text: Click Calculate to see annual savings

steps.name: Step 5
steps.text: View payback period and CO₂ reduction

useCases: Plan home energy upgrades with best return on investment
Compare different efficiency improvements by payback period
Calculate CO₂ reduction from energy efficiency projects
Budget for home improvement projects
seoTips: LED bulbs use 75% less energy than incandescent bulbs
Modern AC units are 30-50% more efficient than older models
Proper insulation can reduce heating/cooling costs by 30%
Smart thermostats save 10-15% on heating and cooling
Solar water heaters can provide 50-80% of hot water needs
commonMistakes: Not considering the full cost including installation
Overestimating savings by not accounting for actual usage patterns
Ignoring maintenance costs for some improvements
Not prioritizing improvements with shortest payback period

faqs.question: Which improvement has the best ROI?
faqs.answer: LED bulbs typically have the fastest payback (under 1 year). Smart thermostats and insulation follow with 2-3 year payback periods.

faqs.question: How much can LED bulbs save?
faqs.answer: LED bulbs use 75% less energy than incandescent and 25% less than CFLs. A typical home can save $100-200 per year.

faqs.question: Is a smart thermostat worth it?
faqs.answer: Yes, smart thermostats typically save 10-15% on heating and cooling, paying for themselves in 1-2 years.

faqs.question: How long do solar water heaters take to pay back?
faqs.answer: Solar water heaters typically pay back in 4-8 years depending on local sun hours and electricity costs.

faqs.question: Should I improve insulation or replace the AC first?
faqs.answer: Generally, improve insulation first. Better insulation reduces the load on your AC, potentially allowing a smaller, cheaper replacement unit.

plastic_footprint.title: Plastic Footprint Calculator
plastic_footprint.description: Calculate your annual plastic consumption and environmental impact
plastic_footprint.containers_tooltip: Number of plastic food containers weekly
plastic_footprint.alt_straws: Avoid straws or use metal alternatives
plastic_footprint.empty_state: Enter your plastic usage to calculate plastic footprint
plastic_footprint.footer_note: 8 million tons of plastic enter oceans annually.

howItWorks.title: How Does the Plastic Footprint Calculator Work?
howItWorks.formula: Annual Plastic = Σ (Items/week × Weight per item × 52 weeks)
howItWorks.explanation: This calculator estimates your annual plastic consumption by multiplying weekly usage of common plastic items by their average weights, then projects CO₂ emissions from plastic production.

steps.name: Step 1
steps.text: Enter weekly number of plastic bottles used

steps.name: Step 2
steps.text: Enter weekly plastic bags consumed

steps.name: Step 3
steps.text: Enter weekly plastic packaging weight in grams

steps.name: Step 4
steps.text: Add straws and food containers used

steps.name: Step 5
steps.text: Click Calculate to see annual plastic footprint

useCases: Track personal plastic consumption for reduction goals
Calculate environmental impact of single-use plastics
Identify biggest sources of plastic waste in your routine
Plan transition to reusable alternatives
seoTips: Average person uses 100+ plastic bottles per year
Plastic production emits 1.8 kg CO₂ per kg of plastic
Only 9% of all plastic ever produced has been recycled
A reusable bottle saves 156 plastic bottles per year
Plastic bags are used for 12 minutes on average but last 1000 years
commonMistakes: Forgetting hidden plastics in packaging and wrapping
Not counting produce bags and small plastic items
Underestimating food container usage from takeout
Assuming all plastic is recyclable - many types are not

faqs.question: How much plastic does the average person use?
faqs.answer: The average person uses about 100 kg of plastic per year, including packaging that's often overlooked.

faqs.question: Which plastic items have the biggest impact?
faqs.answer: Plastic bottles and food packaging account for the majority of personal plastic use. Bottles alone can be 20+ kg per person annually.

faqs.question: How much CO₂ does plastic produce?
faqs.answer: Plastic production emits about 1.8 kg CO₂ per kg of plastic. An average person's plastic use creates 180 kg CO₂ per year.

faqs.question: Are bioplastics better?
faqs.answer: Bioplastics can have lower carbon footprints but often require industrial composting. Reducing overall plastic use is more effective.

faqs.question: What is the best way to reduce plastic use?
faqs.answer: Start with reusable bottles, bags, and containers. These three changes can reduce personal plastic use by 30-50%.

flight_emissions.title: Flight Emissions Calculator
flight_emissions.description: Calculate carbon emissions from your flights
flight_emissions.passengers_tooltip: Number of passengers on the flight
flight_emissions.tip_class: First class produces 5x more emissions than economy
flight_emissions.tip_short: Short flights are less efficient than long flights
flight_emissions.empty_state: Enter flight details to calculate emissions
flight_emissions.footer_note: Calculations are based on industry averages and may vary by aircraft and route.

howItWorks.title: How Does the Flight Emissions Calculator Work?
howItWorks.formula: CO₂ = Distance (km) × Emission factor × Class multiplier × Passengers
howItWorks.explanation: This calculator estimates CO₂ emissions from flights based on distance, travel class, and radiative forcing factor that accounts for emissions released at high altitude.

steps.name: Step 1
steps.text: Select your travel class (economy to first)

steps.name: Step 2
steps.text: Enter the flight distance in kilometers

steps.name: Step 3
steps.text: Enter the number of passengers

steps.name: Step 4
steps.text: Click Calculate to see total emissions

steps.name: Step 5
steps.text: View offset cost and comparison data

useCases: Calculate carbon footprint of business travel for reporting
Compare emissions between flight routes or travel alternatives
Budget for carbon offsetting of flights
Make informed decisions about necessary vs. avoidable flights
seoTips: Aviation accounts for 2.5% of global CO₂ emissions
First class produces 5x more emissions than economy per passenger
A round-trip transatlantic flight produces 1.6 tonnes CO₂
High-altitude emissions have 2-4x the climate impact of ground emissions
Short flights are less efficient due to takeoff and landing fuel use
commonMistakes: Forgetting to include return flights when calculating annual travel
Not accounting for the class multiplier on premium cabins
Ignoring connecting flights which add significant emissions
Underestimating the radiative forcing effect of high-altitude emissions

faqs.question: Why does travel class affect emissions?
faqs.answer: Higher classes have larger seats taking more space, meaning fewer passengers per flight. The aircraft's total emissions are divided among fewer people.

faqs.question: How much CO₂ does a typical flight produce?
faqs.answer: A short-haul flight produces about 0.12 kg CO₂ per km per passenger. Long-haul is more efficient at 0.08 kg CO₂ per km.

faqs.question: Are trains really better than planes?
faqs.answer: Yes, significantly. High-speed trains produce 90% less CO₂ than flights for the same distance.

faqs.question: Should I offset my flights?
faqs.answer: Offsetting helps but reducing flights is better. If you must fly, choose economy, direct routes, and offset through certified programs.

faqs.question: What is radiative forcing?
faqs.answer: Aircraft emissions at high altitudes have enhanced warming effects. A multiplier of 1.9-2.0 is applied to account for this total climate impact.

eco_score.title: Eco Score Calculator
eco_score.description: Assess your environmental friendliness through lifestyle
eco_score.empty_state: Answer the questions to calculate your eco score
eco_score.footer_note: Every small step toward sustainability matters.

suggestions.transport: Use public transport or bike more
suggestions.shopping: Reduce consumption and choose sustainable products

scale_desc.needs_improvement: Needs Improvement - Start with small steps

howItWorks.title: How Does the Eco Score Calculator Work?
howItWorks.formula: Eco Score = Σ (Category score × Weight) / Maximum possible score × 100
howItWorks.explanation: This calculator evaluates your environmental friendliness by scoring your choices across five key lifestyle categories: transportation, diet, energy, recycling, and shopping habits.

steps.name: Step 1
steps.text: Select your main transportation method

steps.name: Step 2
steps.text: Choose your diet type

steps.name: Step 3
steps.text: Select your home energy source

steps.name: Step 4
steps.text: Indicate your recycling frequency

steps.name: Step 5
steps.text: Choose your shopping habits

steps.name: Step 6
steps.text: Click Calculate to see your eco score

useCases: Get a quick assessment of your overall environmental impact
Identify areas where you can improve sustainability
Track progress over time as you make lifestyle changes
Compare your score with sustainable living benchmarks
seoTips: Transportation typically accounts for 30% of personal carbon footprint
Diet choices can reduce your footprint by 20-50%
Switching to renewable energy is the single biggest impact action
Consistent recycling can reduce waste by 30-40%
Mindful consumption prevents emissions from manufacturing
commonMistakes: Overestimating your recycling habits - most people recycle less than they think
Not considering the environmental cost of excessive shopping
Assuming hybrid cars are as green as public transport
Thinking occasional actions count more than consistent habits

faqs.question: What is a good eco score?
faqs.answer: A score above 70 indicates strong environmental habits. 50-70 is average with room for improvement. Below 50 suggests significant changes needed.

faqs.question: Which category has the biggest impact?
faqs.answer: Transportation and diet typically have the largest impact. Switching from car to public transport or reducing meat can have dramatic effects.

faqs.question: How can I quickly improve my score?
faqs.answer: Focus on high-impact changes: use public transport more, reduce meat consumption, switch to green energy if available.

faqs.question: Does recycling really make a difference?
faqs.answer: Yes, but reduction and reuse are even more important. Recycling aluminum saves 95% of the energy needed for new production.

green_commute.title: Green Commute Calculator
green_commute.description: Compare transport methods by environmental impact and cost
green_commute.benefit_money: Save money in the long run
green_commute.empty_state: Enter commute details to compare transport methods
green_commute.footer_note: Choosing green commute benefits you and the environment.

howItWorks.title: How Does the Green Commute Calculator Work?
howItWorks.formula: Annual CO₂ Savings = (Current mode emissions - Alternative mode emissions) × Distance × 2 × Days × 52
howItWorks.explanation: This calculator compares the environmental impact and costs of your current commute method against a greener alternative, calculating annual savings in CO₂, money, and health benefits.

steps.name: Step 1
steps.text: Enter your one-way commute distance in kilometers

steps.name: Step 2
steps.text: Select your current transportation mode

steps.name: Step 3
steps.text: Select an alternative green mode to compare

steps.name: Step 4
steps.text: Enter the number of commute days per week

steps.name: Step 5
steps.text: Click Calculate to see annual savings

useCases: Compare environmental impact of different commute options
Calculate potential savings from switching to public transport or cycling
Justify green commute investments (e-bike, transit pass)
Plan multimodal commuting strategies
seoTips: Cycling to work burns 300-500 calories per hour
Public transport produces 70% less CO₂ per passenger-km than cars
E-bikes make cycling viable for longer distances up to 20km
Car commuters spend 200+ hours per year in traffic
Active commuting reduces risk of heart disease by 30-40%
commonMistakes: Not accounting for total door-to-door time including parking
Underestimating the cost of car ownership (maintenance, insurance)
Ignoring the health benefits of active commuting
Assuming public transport is always slower than driving

faqs.question: How much CO₂ can I save by cycling?
faqs.answer: Switching from car to bicycle saves about 0.2 kg CO₂ per km. A 10km commute saves 800+ kg CO₂ per year.

faqs.question: Is an e-bike worth the investment?
faqs.answer: For commutes of 5-15km, an e-bike typically pays for itself in 1-2 years through fuel and parking savings, plus health benefits.

faqs.question: How does the metro compare to driving?
faqs.answer: Metro produces about 35g CO₂ per passenger-km vs 170g for a car. It's also faster in congested areas.

faqs.question: What are the health benefits of bike commuting?
faqs.answer: Regular cycling commuters have 40% lower risk of heart disease, burn 300-500 calories per hour, and report lower stress.

faqs.question: Can I combine methods?
faqs.answer: Yes, multimodal commuting (bike to station + train) often gives the best balance of time, cost, and environmental impact.

home_energy_audit.title: Home Energy Audit Calculator
home_energy_audit.description: Calculate your home energy consumption and annual cost
home_energy_audit.tip_led: Use LED bulbs instead of traditional bulbs
home_energy_audit.empty_state: Enter energy consumption to perform audit
home_energy_audit.footer_note: Prices are approximate and based on Saudi electricity tariffs.

howItWorks.title: How Does the Home Energy Audit Calculator Work?
howItWorks.formula: Total Cost = Σ (Category kWh × Monthly × 12 × Electricity rate)
howItWorks.explanation: This calculator analyzes your home energy consumption by category, calculating monthly costs, annual expenses, CO₂ emissions, and identifying potential savings opportunities.

steps.name: Step 1
steps.text: Enter monthly lighting and general electricity usage in kWh

steps.name: Step 2
steps.text: Enter heating consumption

steps.name: Step 3
steps.text: Enter air conditioning consumption

steps.name: Step 4
steps.text: Enter water heater consumption

steps.name: Step 5
steps.text: Enter home appliances consumption

steps.name: Step 6
steps.text: Click Calculate to see detailed audit results

useCases: Identify which categories consume the most energy in your home
Calculate annual energy costs for budgeting
Find potential areas for energy savings
Track energy consumption over time
seoTips: Heating and cooling typically account for 50% of home energy use
Water heating is often the second-largest energy expense at 15-20%
Standby power (phantom load) wastes 5-10% of home electricity
Energy-efficient appliances can reduce consumption by 25-50%
LED lighting uses 75% less energy than incandescent bulbs
commonMistakes: Forgetting to include standby power consumption
Not accounting for seasonal variations in heating/cooling
Underestimating water heater consumption
Ignoring inefficient appliances that should be replaced

faqs.question: What is the biggest energy user in most homes?
faqs.answer: Heating and cooling typically account for 40-50% of home energy use, followed by water heating at 15-20%.

faqs.question: How can I reduce my energy consumption quickly?
faqs.answer: Quick wins include: adjusting thermostat by 2°C, using LED bulbs, unplugging unused devices, and running appliances during off-peak hours.

faqs.question: How much energy does air conditioning use?
faqs.answer: Air conditioning can use 3-5 kWh per hour of operation. Setting to 24°C instead of 20°C can save 20-30% of cooling costs.

faqs.question: Should I turn off appliances or leave them on standby?
faqs.answer: Turn them off. Standby power can account for 5-10% of your electricity bill - about 50-100 kWh per month for a typical home.

faqs.question: How often should I do an energy audit?
faqs.answer: Do a basic audit seasonally and a comprehensive audit annually. Track consumption monthly to identify unusual increases.

solar_roi.title: Solar Panel ROI Calculator
solar_roi.description: Calculate solar panel investment return and payback period
solar_roi.empty_state: Enter solar system details to calculate ROI
solar_roi.footer_note: Calculations are estimates based on installation conditions and local sun hours.

howItWorks.title: How Does the Solar Panel ROI Calculator Work?
howItWorks.formula: Annual Production = System size (kW) × Sun hours × 365 × 0.8 (efficiency factor)
howItWorks.explanation: This calculator estimates your return on investment for solar panels by calculating annual energy production, savings, and the time needed to recover your investment.

steps.name: Step 1
steps.text: Enter your solar system size in kilowatts

steps.name: Step 2
steps.text: Enter the total installation cost

steps.name: Step 3
steps.text: Enter your average monthly electricity bill

steps.name: Step 4
steps.text: Enter average daily peak sun hours in your area

steps.name: Step 5
steps.text: Click Calculate to see payback period and ROI

useCases: Evaluate financial viability of residential solar installation
Compare different system sizes and their payback periods
Calculate long-term savings over the 25-year panel lifespan
Plan financing based on expected savings
seoTips: Solar panels typically last 25-30 years with minimal degradation
Most systems pay for themselves in 5-10 years
Solar increases property value by 3-4% on average
Peak sun hours range from 3-6 hours depending on location
Panel efficiency degrades about 0.5% per year
commonMistakes: Not accounting for panel degradation over time (0.5% per year)
Forgetting to include inverter replacement cost (every 10-15 years)
Overestimating sun hours without considering local conditions
Not considering roof orientation and shading

faqs.question: How long do solar panels last?
faqs.answer: Quality solar panels last 25-30 years. Most maintain 80% efficiency after 25 years. Warranties typically guarantee 25 years.

faqs.question: What is a good payback period?
faqs.answer: A payback period of 6-10 years is typical and considered good. After payback, you enjoy essentially free electricity.

faqs.question: How much roof space do I need?
faqs.answer: Roughly 5-7 square meters per kW of solar capacity. A 5kW system needs about 25-35 square meters of roof space.

faqs.question: Do solar panels work on cloudy days?
faqs.answer: Yes, but at reduced efficiency (10-25% of full capacity). Annual production estimates account for average weather conditions.

faqs.question: Should I get battery storage?
faqs.answer: Batteries add cost but provide energy independence and backup power. They're most valuable with time-of-use electricity rates.

flight-emissions-calculator.title: Flight Emissions Calculator
flight-emissions-calculator.description: Calculate carbon emissions from your flights.
flight-emissions-calculator.passengers_tooltip: Number of passengers on the flight
flight-emissions-calculator.comparison_1: First class produces 5x more emissions than economy
flight-emissions-calculator.comparison_2: Short flights are less efficient than long flights
flight-emissions-calculator.empty_state: Enter flight details to calculate emissions
flight-emissions-calculator.footer_note: Calculations are based on industry averages and may vary by aircraft and route.

howItWorks.title: How Does the Flight Emissions Calculator Work?
howItWorks.formula: Total CO₂ = Distance × Base factor × Class multiplier × Radiative forcing (1.9)
howItWorks.explanation: This calculator estimates flight emissions using ICAO methodology, factoring in distance, travel class space allocation, and the enhanced climate impact of high-altitude emissions.

steps.name: Step 1
steps.text: Select your travel class from the dropdown

steps.name: Step 2
steps.text: Enter the total flight distance in kilometers

steps.name: Step 3
steps.text: Enter the number of passengers traveling

steps.name: Step 4
steps.text: Click Calculate to see total and per-passenger emissions

steps.name: Step 5
steps.text: View offset requirements and costs

useCases: Calculate business travel carbon footprint for corporate reporting
Compare emission impact of different flight options
Estimate carbon offset costs before booking flights
Track annual flight emissions for personal sustainability goals
seoTips: Long-haul flights are more efficient per km than short-haul
Business class emissions are 2.5x economy due to space
First class produces 5x the emissions of economy class
Direct flights have lower emissions than connecting routes
Average transatlantic flight: 1-2 tonnes CO₂ per passenger
commonMistakes: Forgetting round-trip flights double your emissions
Not including connecting flights in calculations
Ignoring the radiative forcing multiplier for altitude effects
Underestimating premium cabin impact on emissions

faqs.question: Why do premium cabins have higher emissions?
faqs.answer: Premium seats occupy more aircraft space, reducing passenger capacity. The flight's total emissions are divided among fewer passengers.

faqs.question: What is radiative forcing?
faqs.answer: Emissions at high altitudes have greater climate impact. A factor of 1.9 is applied to account for contrails, cirrus clouds, and nitrogen oxide effects.

faqs.question: How can I reduce my flight emissions?
faqs.answer: Fly economy class, choose direct routes, avoid short flights where trains are viable, and consider video meetings instead.

faqs.question: Are newer aircraft more efficient?
faqs.answer: Yes, modern aircraft use 15-20% less fuel. The Boeing 787 and Airbus A350 are among the most efficient for long-haul flights.

rainwater_harvesting.title: Rainwater Harvesting Calculator
rainwater_harvesting.description: Calculate collectable rainwater amount from your roof
rainwater_harvesting.rainfall_tooltip: Average annual rainfall in your area
rainwater_harvesting.info_filtration: Need filtration system for household uses
rainwater_harvesting.empty_state: Enter roof details to calculate rainwater amount
rainwater_harvesting.footer_note: Rainwater harvesting conserves water and reduces runoff.

howItWorks.title: How Does the Rainwater Harvesting Calculator Work?
howItWorks.formula: Annual Collection = Roof area (m²) × Annual rainfall (mm) × Efficiency (0.8-0.9) × 0.001
howItWorks.explanation: This calculator estimates how much rainwater you can collect from your roof annually, accounting for collection system efficiency and recommending appropriate storage tank sizes.

steps.name: Step 1
steps.text: Enter your roof collection area in square meters

steps.name: Step 2
steps.text: Enter your area's annual rainfall in millimeters

steps.name: Step 3
steps.text: Enter your collection system efficiency (typically 80-90%)

steps.name: Step 4
steps.text: Click Calculate to see annual collection potential

steps.name: Step 5
steps.text: View recommended tank size and cost savings

useCases: Plan rainwater harvesting system capacity
Calculate potential water bill savings
Size storage tanks appropriately for your needs
Assess feasibility of rainwater harvesting in your area
seoTips: A 100m² roof in moderate rainfall (800mm) can collect 64,000 liters yearly
Rainwater is ideal for irrigation - plants prefer it over tap water
First-flush diverters improve water quality significantly
Tank size should hold 2-4 weeks of expected use
Rainwater harvesting reduces stormwater runoff by 50-75%
commonMistakes: Overestimating collection without accounting for efficiency losses
Not planning for seasonal rainfall variation
Undersizing tanks and missing peak collection periods
Forgetting maintenance requirements for gutters and filters

faqs.question: How much rainwater can I collect?
faqs.answer: Multiply roof area (m²) by annual rainfall (m) by 0.8 efficiency. A 100m² roof with 800mm rainfall collects about 64,000 liters yearly.

faqs.question: What tank size do I need?
faqs.answer: Tank size depends on rainfall patterns. Generally, size for 2-4 weeks of use or 3-5% of annual collection, whichever is larger.

faqs.question: Can I use rainwater for drinking?
faqs.answer: With proper filtration and UV treatment, yes. However, most systems are designed for non-potable uses like irrigation and toilet flushing.

faqs.question: What is collection efficiency?
faqs.answer: Not all rain is captured - some evaporates, splashes, or is lost in first-flush diversion. Typical efficiency is 80-90% of theoretical maximum.

faqs.question: Is rainwater harvesting cost-effective?
faqs.answer: ROI depends on local water costs and rainfall. In areas with expensive water or unreliable supply, systems often pay back in 5-10 years.

recycling_impact.title: Recycling Impact Calculator
recycling_impact.description: Calculates CO2 saved by recycling different materials
recycling_impact.formula_explanation: Savings calculated based on average CO2 reduction per kg of recycled material: Paper (0.9kg), Plastic (1.5kg), Glass (0.3kg), Metal (2.5kg).
recycling_impact.use_case_3: Saves energy compared to raw material processing
recycling_impact.step_focus: Focus on one area at a time
recycling_impact.step_share: Share your journey to inspire others
recycling_impact.empty_state: Answer questions to assess your lifestyle sustainability
recycling_impact.footer_note: Sustainability is a journey, not a destination. Every step counts.

suggestions.energy: Switching to solar saves 3000 kg CO₂
suggestions.transport: Using public transport saves 2500 kg CO₂

recycling_impact.info_description: Recycling reduces greenhouse gas emissions by avoiding the need to extract and process new raw materials.
recycling_impact.error_at_least_one: Please enter the weight of at least one material

howItWorks.title: How Does the Recycling Impact Calculator Work?
howItWorks.formula: CO₂ Saved = Σ (Material weight × Emission factor per kg)
howItWorks.explanation: This calculator estimates the CO₂ savings from recycling various materials by comparing the emissions from recycled material production versus virgin material production.

steps.name: Step 1
steps.text: Enter the weight of paper recycled in kilograms

steps.name: Step 2
steps.text: Enter the weight of plastic recycled

steps.name: Step 3
steps.text: Enter the weight of glass recycled

steps.name: Step 4
steps.text: Enter the weight of metal recycled

steps.name: Step 5
steps.text: Click Calculate to see total CO₂ savings

useCases: Track environmental impact of household recycling efforts
Calculate corporate recycling benefits for sustainability reports
Motivate recycling by visualizing actual CO₂ savings
Compare impact of recycling different materials
seoTips: Recycling aluminum saves 95% of energy vs. virgin production
Paper recycling saves 0.9 kg CO₂ per kg recycled
Plastic recycling saves 1.5 kg CO₂ per kg recycled
Metal recycling provides the highest CO₂ savings at 2.5 kg/kg
Glass recycling saves 0.3 kg CO₂ per kg recycled
commonMistakes: Contaminating recyclables with food waste, making them non-recyclable
Wish-cycling - putting non-recyclable items in recycling bins
Not checking local recycling guidelines which vary by area
Forgetting to rinse containers before recycling

faqs.question: Which material is most important to recycle?
faqs.answer: Metal (especially aluminum) provides the highest CO₂ savings per kg. However, plastic recycling is crucial due to its persistence in the environment.

faqs.question: Does recycling actually help the environment?
faqs.answer: Yes. Recycling uses significantly less energy than virgin production: 95% less for aluminum, 70% less for plastic, and 60% less for paper.

faqs.question: What happens to recycled materials?
faqs.answer: They're processed into new products. Aluminum becomes new cans, plastic becomes fiber or packaging, paper becomes cardboard or new paper products.

faqs.question: Can all plastics be recycled?
faqs.answer: No. Types 1 (PET) and 2 (HDPE) are widely recyclable. Types 3-7 vary by local facility. Check the recycling symbol on the item.

faqs.question: How much does the average person recycle?
faqs.answer: The global average is about 9% of plastic, 65% of paper, 30% of glass, and 35% of metal. These rates vary significantly by country.

waste.title: Waste Calculator
waste.description: Calculate your waste generation and environmental impact
waste.tip_meal: Plan meals to reduce food waste
waste.empty_state: Enter waste amounts to calculate total production
waste.footer_note: Average person produces 1.5-2 kg of waste daily.

howItWorks.title: How Does the Waste Calculator Work?
howItWorks.formula: Annual Waste = Daily waste × 365 | Landfill Emissions = Organic waste × Methane factor
howItWorks.explanation: This calculator estimates your household waste production and its environmental impact, including landfill emissions from organic waste decomposition.

steps.name: Step 1
steps.text: Enter daily food waste in kilograms

steps.name: Step 2
steps.text: Enter daily plastic waste

steps.name: Step 3
steps.text: Enter daily paper waste

steps.name: Step 4
steps.text: Enter daily other waste

steps.name: Step 5
steps.text: Enter household size for per-capita calculations

steps.name: Step 6
steps.text: Click Calculate to see total waste and emissions

useCases: Track household waste generation over time
Identify which waste categories can be reduced
Calculate environmental impact of waste for sustainability goals
Compare waste per capita against averages
seoTips: Average person produces 1.5-2 kg of waste daily
Food waste in landfills produces methane, 25x worse than CO₂
40% of household waste can be composted or recycled
Plastic takes 400-1000 years to decompose in landfills
Zero-waste lifestyle can reduce waste by 90%
commonMistakes: Not tracking all waste categories including hidden packaging
Underestimating food waste which is often the largest category
Forgetting to count waste produced outside the home
Confusing recycled waste with total waste

faqs.question: How much waste does the average person produce?
faqs.answer: The global average is about 1.2 kg per day, but this ranges from 0.5 kg in low-income countries to over 2 kg in high-income countries.

faqs.question: What percentage of waste is food?
faqs.answer: Food waste typically makes up 30-40% of household waste. Much of this could be composted instead of landfilled.

faqs.question: Why does organic waste produce methane?
faqs.answer: Organic matter decomposing without oxygen (as in landfills) produces methane. Composting with oxygen produces CO₂, which is 25x less harmful.

faqs.question: How can I reduce my waste?
faqs.answer: Follow the 5 Rs: Refuse what you don't need, Reduce what you do need, Reuse what you can, Recycle what you can't reuse, Rot (compost) the rest.

faqs.question: What is the biggest contributor to household waste?
faqs.answer: Food and food packaging typically account for 40-50% of household waste by weight.

water_footprint.title: Water Footprint Calculator
water_footprint.description: Calculate your annual water footprint including virtual water
water_footprint.laundry_tooltip: Number of laundry loads per week
water_footprint.car_wash_tooltip: Number of car washes per month
water_footprint.empty_state: Enter your lifestyle information to calculate water footprint
water_footprint.footer_note: Virtual water is the water used in producing goods and food.

howItWorks.title: How Does the Water Footprint Calculator Work?
howItWorks.formula: Total Water Footprint = Direct water use + Virtual water (food production + goods)
howItWorks.explanation: This calculator estimates your total water footprint by combining direct water use (showers, laundry) with virtual water embedded in the food you eat and products you use.

steps.name: Step 1
steps.text: Select your diet type from the dropdown

steps.name: Step 2
steps.text: Enter average daily shower duration in minutes

steps.name: Step 3
steps.text: Enter weekly laundry loads

steps.name: Step 4
steps.text: Enter monthly car washes

steps.name: Step 5
steps.text: Click Calculate to see total water footprint

useCases: Understand the hidden water in your food choices
Compare water footprint of different diets
Identify major contributors to your water use
Set goals for water footprint reduction
seoTips: Virtual water accounts for 92% of total water footprint
A meat-heavy diet uses 5,000+ liters per day
A vegan diet uses 2,000-2,500 liters per day
1 kg of beef requires 15,000 liters of water to produce
Direct household use is only 100-200 liters per day
commonMistakes: Focusing only on direct water use while ignoring virtual water
Not realizing meat production dominates water footprint
Underestimating the water in processed foods and drinks
Forgetting water embedded in clothing and consumer goods

faqs.question: What is virtual water?
faqs.answer: Virtual water is the water used to produce goods and food. A cotton t-shirt requires 2,700 liters, a smartphone about 12,000 liters.

faqs.question: Why does beef use so much water?
faqs.answer: Cattle need water for drinking, but mainly for growing feed crops. It takes about 15,000 liters to produce 1 kg of beef over the animal's lifetime.

faqs.question: How can I reduce my water footprint?
faqs.answer: The biggest impact comes from dietary changes. Reducing beef consumption has a larger effect than all direct water-saving measures combined.

faqs.question: What is a sustainable water footprint?
faqs.answer: A sustainable footprint is about 1,240 liters per person per day. Most people in developed countries use 3,000-5,000 liters.

faqs.question: Does taking shorter showers really help?
faqs.answer: It helps, but direct water is only 5-10% of your footprint. A 5-minute shorter shower saves 50 liters, but eating 100g less beef saves 1,500 liters.

vehicle_emissions.title: Vehicle Emissions Calculator
vehicle_emissions.description: Calculate CO₂ emissions from your vehicle based on fuel type and distance
vehicle_emissions.tip_drive: Avoid aggressive driving and high speeds
vehicle_emissions.empty_state: Enter vehicle details to calculate emissions
vehicle_emissions.footer_note: Prices and emissions are estimates and may vary by vehicle and conditions.

howItWorks.title: How Does the Vehicle Emissions Calculator Work?
howItWorks.formula: CO₂ = Distance (km) × Fuel consumption (L/100km) × Emission factor × 0.01
howItWorks.explanation: This calculator estimates your vehicle's CO₂ emissions based on the fuel type, fuel consumption rate, and distance traveled using standard emission factors for each fuel type.

steps.name: Step 1
steps.text: Select your vehicle's fuel type

steps.name: Step 2
steps.text: Enter your fuel consumption in liters per 100 km

steps.name: Step 3
steps.text: Enter the distance you want to calculate emissions for

steps.name: Step 4
steps.text: Click Calculate to see CO₂ emissions

steps.name: Step 5
steps.text: View fuel cost and tree offset requirements

useCases: Calculate emissions for specific trips or routes
Compare environmental impact of different vehicles
Track monthly or annual vehicle emissions
Justify vehicle upgrade to hybrid or electric
seoTips: Petrol produces 2.31 kg CO₂ per liter burned
Diesel produces 2.68 kg CO₂ per liter but is more fuel-efficient
Hybrids typically produce 30-50% less CO₂ than petrol cars
Electric vehicles have zero direct emissions
Maintaining proper tire pressure improves efficiency by 3%
commonMistakes: Using manufacturer fuel consumption which is often optimistic
Not accounting for city vs highway driving differences
Forgetting that electric vehicles have indirect emissions from electricity
Ignoring the impact of driving style on actual emissions

faqs.question: Which fuel type produces more CO₂?
faqs.answer: Per liter, diesel produces more CO₂ (2.68 kg) than petrol (2.31 kg). However, diesel engines are more efficient, often resulting in similar emissions per km.

faqs.question: Are electric vehicles truly zero-emission?
faqs.answer: They have zero direct emissions, but total emissions depend on how electricity is generated. In clean grids, EVs produce 70-90% less lifetime emissions.

faqs.question: How can I reduce my vehicle emissions?
faqs.answer: Maintain proper tire pressure, avoid aggressive driving, reduce AC use, remove roof racks when not needed, and combine trips.

faqs.question: How much does driving style affect emissions?
faqs.answer: Aggressive driving (rapid acceleration, hard braking) can increase fuel consumption and emissions by 15-30%.

faqs.question: Should I switch to a hybrid?
faqs.answer: If you drive mostly in cities with stop-and-go traffic, hybrids can reduce emissions by 30-50%. For highway driving, the benefit is smaller.

sustainable_lifestyle.title: Sustainable Lifestyle Calculator
sustainable_lifestyle.description: Assess your lifestyle sustainability and get personalized recommendations to reduce your environmental impact.
sustainable_lifestyle.transport_tooltip: Select your main mode of transportation
sustainable_lifestyle.waste_tooltip: How do you manage waste and recycling?
sustainable_lifestyle.planet_text: Earths needed if everyone lived like you

suggestions.transport: Use public transport, bike, or consider an electric vehicle
suggestions.diet: Reduce meat consumption and choose local, seasonal foods
suggestions.water: Install water-saving devices and reduce usage
suggestions.shopping: Buy less, choose sustainable products, avoid fast fashion

sustainable_lifestyle.info_description: Small changes in daily habits can significantly reduce your environmental impact and help protect our planet for future generations.
sustainable_lifestyle.empty_state: Answer the questions to calculate your sustainability score
sustainable_lifestyle.step_focus: Focus on one area at a time
sustainable_lifestyle.step_share: Share your journey to inspire others
sustainable_lifestyle.footer_note: Sustainability is a journey, not a destination. Every step counts.

howItWorks.formula: Sustainability Score = Σ (Category score × Impact weight) / Max score × 100
howItWorks.explanation: This calculator evaluates your lifestyle choices across six key environmental impact areas: energy, transportation, diet, waste management, water usage, and shopping habits. Each category is weighted by its relative environmental impact.

steps.name: Step 1
steps.text: Select your primary energy source

steps.name: Step 2

steps.name: Step 3

steps.name: Step 4
steps.text: Indicate your waste management practices

steps.name: Step 5
steps.text: Select your water usage level

steps.name: Step 6
steps.text: Choose your shopping habits

steps.name: Step 7
steps.text: Click Calculate to see your sustainability score

useCases: Get a comprehensive sustainability assessment
Identify highest-impact areas for improvement
Track sustainability progress over time
Calculate your ecological footprint in Earth equivalents
seoTips: Transportation and diet typically have the largest individual impact
Switching to renewable energy can reduce footprint by 30-40%
Zero-waste practices can reduce waste by 90%
The average American footprint requires 5 Earths to sustain
Simple changes can reduce your footprint by 20% in the first year
commonMistakes: Focusing on low-impact changes while ignoring high-impact ones
Underestimating the impact of diet on environmental footprint
Thinking technology alone will solve sustainability challenges
Comparing yourself to the average instead of sustainable targets

faqs.question: What is an ecological footprint?
faqs.answer: It measures how much land and water is needed to produce what you consume and absorb your waste. Sustainable level is 1.7 hectares per person.

faqs.question: What does 'X Earths' mean?
faqs.answer: If everyone lived like you, we would need X Earths to provide resources. The goal is to live within 1 Earth's capacity.

faqs.question: Which lifestyle change has the biggest impact?
faqs.answer: Flying less, driving less, eating plant-based, and using renewable energy are the four highest-impact personal changes.

faqs.question: How can I improve my score quickly?
faqs.answer: Start with easy wins: switch to green energy if available, reduce meat to 2-3 days/week, and use public transport when possible.

faqs.question: Is a perfect score achievable?
faqs.answer: A perfect score requires significant lifestyle changes. Focus on continuous improvement rather than perfection - every improvement matters.

solar-panel-roi-calculator.title: Solar Panel ROI Calculator
solar-panel-roi-calculator.description: Calculate your solar panel investment return and payback period.
solar-panel-roi-calculator.system_size_tooltip: Total capacity of your solar panel system
solar-panel-roi-calculator.install_cost_tooltip: Total cost including panels and installation
solar-panel-roi-calculator.sun_hours_tooltip: Average daily peak sun hours in your area

solar-panel-roi-calculator.empty_state: Enter your solar system details to calculate ROI
solar-panel-roi-calculator.footer_note: Calculations are estimates based on installation conditions and local sun hours.

howItWorks.title: How Does the Solar Panel ROI Calculator Work?
howItWorks.formula: ROI = ((Annual savings × 25 years) - Installation cost) / Installation cost × 100%
howItWorks.explanation: This calculator projects your solar investment return by estimating annual energy production based on system size and local sun hours, then calculating savings over the typical 25-year panel lifespan.

steps.name: Step 1
steps.text: Enter your proposed solar system size in kilowatts

steps.name: Step 2
steps.text: Enter the total installation cost including panels and labor

steps.name: Step 3
steps.text: Enter your current average monthly electricity bill

steps.name: Step 4
steps.text: Enter average peak sun hours in your area

steps.name: Step 5
steps.text: Click Calculate to see payback period and ROI

useCases: Evaluate solar panel investment before purchase
Compare quotes from different solar installers
Understand long-term financial benefits of solar
Plan financing based on payback timeline
seoTips: Average payback period for solar is 6-10 years
Solar panels maintain 80%+ efficiency after 25 years
ROI over 25 years typically exceeds 200-400%
Solar can increase home value by 3-4%
Peak sun hours vary from 3-6 hours by location
commonMistakes: Not factoring in panel degradation of 0.5% per year
Forgetting inverter replacement costs every 10-15 years
Overestimating sun hours without considering local weather
Ignoring roof orientation impact on production

faqs.question: What affects solar ROI the most?
faqs.answer: Installation cost, local electricity rates, sun hours, and roof orientation have the biggest impact on ROI.

faqs.question: How accurate is the payback estimate?
faqs.answer: Estimates are within 10-15% for most installations. Actual results depend on weather patterns and electricity rate changes.

faqs.question: Should I wait for better technology?
faqs.answer: Solar technology improves slowly (1-2% per year), while electricity costs rise. Waiting usually costs more than it saves.

faqs.question: What is the typical system size for a home?
faqs.answer: Most homes need 5-10 kW systems. A 5kW system powers an average home and requires about 30-35 m² of roof space.

faqs.question: Should I get battery storage?
faqs.answer: Batteries add cost but provide energy independence and emergency backup. They are most valuable with time-of-use electricity rates.

tree_planting.title: Tree Planting Impact Calculator
tree_planting.description: Calculate the environmental impact of planting trees including CO₂ offset, oxygen production, and ecosystem benefits.
tree_planting.trees_tooltip: How many trees you plan to plant or have planted
tree_planting.age_tooltip: How old the trees are or will be
tree_planting.type_tooltip: Different tree types have different CO₂ absorption rates
tree_planting.formula_explanation: Trees absorb CO₂ through photosynthesis, produce oxygen, filter water, prevent erosion, and provide habitat for wildlife. A single mature tree can absorb 21 kg of CO₂ per year.
tree_planting.info_description: Trees are nature's carbon capture technology. They absorb CO₂, produce oxygen, cool the environment, filter water, and support biodiversity.
tree_planting.use_case_1: Combat climate change by removing CO₂ from the atmosphere
tree_planting.use_case_2: Improve air quality and reduce urban heat islands
tree_planting.use_case_3: Provide habitat for wildlife and preserve biodiversity
tree_planting.error_required: Please enter the number of trees and their age

howItWorks.title: How Does the Tree Planting Impact Calculator Work?
howItWorks.formula: CO₂ Offset = Number of trees × Annual absorption rate × Age | Oxygen = Trees × 120 kg/year × Age
howItWorks.explanation: This calculator estimates the cumulative environmental benefits of tree planting. Different tree species have varying CO₂ absorption rates, with tropical trees being most efficient at approximately 28 kg CO₂ per year.

steps.name: Step 1
steps.text: Enter the number of trees you plan to plant or have planted

steps.name: Step 2
steps.text: Enter the age of the trees (or projected age)

steps.name: Step 3
steps.text: Select the tree type based on species category

steps.name: Step 4
steps.text: View total CO₂ offset, oxygen production, and other benefits

steps.name: Step 5
steps.text: See the monetary value of ecosystem services provided

useCases: Calculate carbon offset from reforestation projects
Plan corporate tree planting initiatives
Understand personal environmental impact of backyard planting
Justify tree preservation policies with quantified benefits
seoTips: A deciduous tree absorbs about 21 kg CO₂ per year
Tropical trees are 30% more efficient at carbon capture
One mature tree produces 120 kg of oxygen annually
Trees filter approximately 40,000 liters of water per year
Tree planting has an ROI of $50-100 per tree in ecosystem services
commonMistakes: Not accounting for tree mortality rates (typically 10-20%)
Forgetting that young trees absorb less CO₂ than mature trees
Planting non-native species that don't thrive in local conditions
Ignoring ongoing maintenance requirements

faqs.question: How much CO₂ does one tree absorb per year?
faqs.answer: A mature tree absorbs approximately 21 kg of CO₂ per year, though this varies by species, age, and environment. Tropical trees can absorb up to 28 kg annually.

faqs.question: How long does it take for a tree to become carbon positive?
faqs.answer: Most trees become net carbon positive within 1-2 years after planting, once they are established and growing actively.

faqs.question: Which trees are best for carbon capture?
faqs.answer: Fast-growing tropical species and large deciduous trees like oak and maple are most effective. Native species adapted to local conditions perform best long-term.

faqs.question: How many trees needed to offset my carbon footprint?
faqs.answer: For an average footprint of 4 tons CO₂/year, you would need approximately 190 mature trees to fully offset annual emissions.

faqs.question: What other benefits do trees provide besides CO₂ absorption?
faqs.answer: Trees produce oxygen, filter water and air pollutants, prevent soil erosion, reduce urban heat, provide wildlife habitat, and increase property values by 10-20%.
